Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Omission of Tamponade Dressings after Haemorrhoidectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients with grade III or IV haemorrhoids were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: Patients with grade III or IV haemorrhoids were randomised 1:1 to either no tamponade (intervention) or tamponade (control) groups.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to either no tamponade (intervention) or tamponade (control) groups.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated whether omitting tamponade dressings post-haemorrhoidectomy reduces postoperative pain without increasing severe bleeding risk.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were maximum pain intensity within 48 hours post-surgery (superiority) and severe bleeding requiring surgical re-intervention within 7 days (non-inferiority).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was centre-stratified with variable block sizes, and allocation was concealed via a web-based tool.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between May 2017 and November 2020, 754 patients were randomised (366 intervention, 359 control).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group reported lower median pain intensity (5, i.q.r. 3–7) compared to the control group (6, i.q.r. 4–7), P < 0.001. Severe bleeding occurred in 1.1% of patients in both groups, with a non-inferiority margin of −0.03% (90% CI −1.47% to +1.41%).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with 10 serious adverse events recorded (3 intervention, 7 control), including urinary retention, wound infections, fever, and vomiting.
